support_summary: The ratio of Bax to the anti-apoptotic protein Bcl-2 is increased by high expression of activated ATF6, promoting apoptosis.

functions.cellular_process: During severe ER stress, high expression of the activated nuclear form of ATF6 (p50ATF6) leads to the transcriptional downregulation of the anti-apoptotic gene Bcl-2.
functions.effect_description: This repression of Bcl-2 transcription results in decreased Bcl-2 mRNA and protein levels. The reduction of the anti-apoptotic Bcl-2 protein, concurrent with the upregulation of pro-apoptotic proteins like Bax, significantly increases the Bax/Bcl-2 ratio, thereby lowering the threshold for initiating the mitochondrial apoptotic pathway.
biological_consequence: Severe ER Stress → ATF6 activation and nuclear translocation → Transcriptional downregulation of Bcl-2 gene → Decreased Bcl-2 protein levels → Increased Bax/Bcl-2 ratio → Sensitization to mitochondrial apoptosis
specific_effects: Overexpression of active ATF6 downregulates both mRNA and protein levels of Bcl-2 in vascular endothelial cells under ER stress.

evidence.paper_title: High expression of active ATF6 aggravates endoplasmic reticulum stress-induced vascular endothelial cell apoptosis through the mitochondrial apoptotic pathway
